hopobject.name: Page
hopobject.body: A First Class stamp phyto prosta plus blanche bresson Botsford’s memoir, A Life of Privilege, Mostly, gives a very entertaining account of the world Janet and Donald Malcolm entered. Socially, The New Yorker was something of a club – that had been true since Dorothy Parker’s days, and Malcolm confirms that they felt like part of one when they were there. In her Paris Review interview, Malcolm said that she and the other women on the staff wrote to impress the men. The ‘aggression’ in the writing was ‘coupled with flirtation’. ‘It was like a harem,’ she tells me. ‘The wives would be competing with each other for the attention of the man.’ Malcolm pauses. ‘This is the first time I’ve thought about it in these terms, which seem a little excessive.’
